title: At $1 each, these two homes comes with a catch - The Boston Globe
text:
By Katheleen Conti Globe Staff February 24, 2017 They are very likely the best real estate “deals” in town. 
Both are two-story red brick buildings, one with 18 rooms, two kitchens, four bathrooms, and eight bedrooms; the other a little bit smaller with two kitchens, four bathrooms, and six bedrooms. 
For just $1 each. 
Of course, there is a catch: You have to move them — mostly at your own expense. 
The duplexes are former officers’ and doctors’ quarters on the grounds of the Brighton Marine Health Center in the outer Boston neighborhood, and have to be moved to make way for a new housing development. Brighton Marine and the developer had wanted to demolish the 77-year-old buildings, but, under pressure from Massachusetts historic preservation officials, agreed to try to sell them for removal. If not sold 120 days from the day of the listing , the buildings will be demolished. 
The agreement , reached last summer, allows the health center and developer WinnCompanies to move forward on a 102-unit apartment building, most of which will be priced as affordable housing. ans will be given preference for the apartments. The Architectural Team 
The two duplexes are to be sold within 120 days, or they will be demolished to make way for the construction of a new, 102-unit apartment building (seen above, in a rendering). 
There are four older buildings at the location; originally, the plan was to demolish all but one. But then the Massachusetts Historical Commission and its overseer, lifelong Brighton resident and Secretary of State William F. Galvin, sought to protect the former residences. Advertisement 
The health center and Winn agreed to keep a second building and move it to another spot on the campus, and to see if they could sell the other two for $1 each, said Christopher Fleming, senior project director at WinnCompanies. 
“We’re giving away two buildings for a buck. We’re anxious to get going; there is such a demand,” Fleming said. “Hopefully we’ll find someone interested in preserving history and has a plot of land and they’d like to utilize it.” 
Galvin said he would prefer that the buildings remain in the neighborhood, and has talked up their sale to local nonprofit and community development groups. Interest, however, is hard to gauge. 
“The buildings are structurally in very good condition; they’re attractive looking, despite what some people think,” Galvin said. “We’re hopeful one of the community groups or other entities will come forward to take the buildings. If they could be of another use to the community, it would be ideal.” 
Winn has agreed to provide $34,000 for the relocation of each building — about what the company had estimated it would cost to demolish them, Fleming said. The properties are featured on a website aimed at history buffs and potential buyers at www.ownbrightonhistory.com . 
Whether relocated or demolished, Brighton Marine Center is eager to get them off the site, said spokeswoman Karen Schwartzman. “This begins the period of 120 days where a person or institution can pay $1 and relocate those buildings to some other site they want to put them to, so we can go ahead and build our affordable housing units,” Schwartzman said. “We’ve had no use for them for quite some time.” 
‘We’re giving away two buildings for a buck. We’re anxious to get going; there is such a demand.’ 
The project, which is counting on public funding, could break ground later this year, Fleming said, adding that the delay over the quarters has likely pushed the project beyond the $41 million estimate. GLOBE FILE PHOTO
